R.content: since concept of democracy has always been suicidal, if there is to be a democracy to come must think life otherwise, life and the force of life [contra to Aristotle’s actuality as life?]
R.linkedContent: since concept of democracy has always been suicidal, if there is to be a democracy to come must think life otherwise, life and the force of life [contra to Aristotle’s actuality as life?]

FL.content: for Benjamin, mythological violence of law sacrifices the living, whereas divine violence sacrifices life to save the living (destructive)
FL.linkedContent: for Benjamin, mythological violence of law sacrifices the living, whereas divine violence sacrifices life to save the living (destructive)

FL.content: for Benjamin, what is sacred is the justice of life not mere life
FL.linkedContent: for Benjamin, what is sacred is the justice of life not mere life

LOBL.content: “What is life?” asks of its essence and its value
LOBL.linkedContent: “What is life?” asks of its essence and its value

LOBL.content: life being drawn through by a line, edge where it is impossible to settle: arreté
LOBL.linkedContent: life being drawn through by a line, edge where it is impossible to settle: arreté

LOBL.content: more-than-life (sur-vie) marks a reprieve, excess triumphs over life, worth more than eternity of life but presents itself before the arrêt de mort
LOBL.linkedContent: more-than-life (sur-vie) marks a reprieve, excess triumphs over life, worth more than eternity of life but presents itself before the arrêt de mort

LOBL.content: how do we let a text live? letting someone read is like letting them live [re: Derrida pointing us toward Blanchot]
LOBL.linkedContent: how do we let a text live? letting someone read is like letting them live [re: Derrida pointing us toward Blanchot]

SPOM.content: je voudrais apprendre à vivre enfin (I would like to learn to live finally)
SPOM.linkedContent: je voudrais apprendre à vivre enfin (I would like to learn to live finally)

SPOM.content: man’s life always more than a paradigm, other than a symbol > a proper name (see p. 220 on man) [one should never speak of the assassination of a man as a figure? martydom]
SPOM.linkedContent: man’s life always more than a paradigm, other than a symbol > a proper name (see p. 220 on man) [one should never speak of the assassination of a man as a figure? martydom]

SPOM.content: commitment of justice, to whom? to life (natural life, life of spirit) of living being > that this is irrefutable carries justice beyond present life, non pas vers la mort mais vers une sur-vie, where life & death are traces of traces
SPOM.linkedContent: commitment of justice, to whom? to life (natural life, life of spirit) of living being > that this is irrefutable carries justice beyond present life, non pas vers la mort mais vers une sur-vie, where life & death are traces of traces

SPOM.content: alors il y a de l’esprit, des esprits, et il faut compter avec eux > le plus d’un
SPOM.linkedContent: alors il y a de l’esprit, des esprits, et il faut compter avec eux > le plus d’un

SPOM.content: the closure or principle of ruin (see p. 220 on ash) of a philosophy of life, since negativity must be there
SPOM.linkedContent: the closure or principle of ruin (see p. 220 on ash) of a philosophy of life, since negativity must be there

A.content: via Seneca & Diderot, one would guard jealously one’s time above all else; to “master” “my life” > know difference btwn giving one’s time & wasting one’s time
A.linkedContent: via Seneca & Diderot, one would guard jealously one’s time above all else; to “master” “my life” > know difference btwn giving one’s time & wasting one’s time

VM.content: Hegel’s speculative logic: living logic which reconciles formal tautology and empirical heterology [after having thought prophetic discourse in preface to Phenom…]
VM.linkedContent: Hegel’s speculative logic: living logic which reconciles formal tautology and empirical heterology [after having thought prophetic discourse in preface to Phenom…]

PP.content: pharmakon is but a formula learned by heart, dead, rigid knowledge shut up (enfermé) in biblia, foreign to living knowledge and dialectic
PP.linkedContent: pharmakon is but a formula learned by heart, dead, rigid knowledge shut up (enfermé) in biblia, foreign to living knowledge and dialectic

PP.content: living-beings, father and son, are announced to us w/in household (domesticité) of logos
PP.linkedContent: living-beings, father and son, are announced to us w/in household (domesticité) of logos

PP.content: writing stripped of its path-breaking force, pure repetition, dead repetition, tautological, hollow, repetition of death > writing is not living repetition of the living
PP.linkedContent: writing stripped of its path-breaking force, pure repetition, dead repetition, tautological, hollow, repetition of death > writing is not living repetition of the living

PP.content: two tautologies, repetitions: 1) life coming back to itself: eidos, logos, mnēmē, phōnē, requires dialectics, didactics 2) life going out of itself beyond return, unreserved spending, irreducible excess, play of supplement [can’t think these apart from one another]
PP.linkedContent: two tautologies, repetitions: 1) life coming back to itself: eidos, logos, mnēmē, phōnē, requires dialectics, didactics 2) life going out of itself beyond return, unreserved spending, irreducible excess, play of supplement [can’t think these apart from one another]

VP.content: phenomenology (MOP in form of ideality) is also a philosophy of life, death is an empirical and extrinsic accident, everything is light, living light, blazes open passage to reduction
VP.linkedContent: phenomenology (MOP in form of ideality) is also a philosophy of life, death is an empirical and extrinsic accident, everything is light, living light, blazes open passage to reduction

VP.content: metaphor, concept of life allows Husserl to assert a parallelism btwn empirical life and transcendental life, which are radically heterogenous to each other [is Husserl’s parallelism different from that of transcendental psychologism? see pp. 11-2]
VP.linkedContent: metaphor, concept of life allows Husserl to assert a parallelism btwn empirical life and transcendental life, which are radically heterogenous to each other [is Husserl’s parallelism different from that of transcendental psychologism? see pp. 11-2]

VP.content: strange unity of life in Husserl: 1) biological life 2) concept of psychē is life as self-relation > the pre-transcendental becomes the ultra-transcendental, Derrida says maybe concept of life calls for another name
VP.linkedContent: strange unity of life in Husserl: 1) biological life 2) concept of psychē is life as self-relation > the pre-transcendental becomes the ultra-transcendental, Derrida says maybe concept of life calls for another name

VP.content: presence to itself of animating act, this intimacy of life to itself is why we say speech is alive, we hear our voice, thus the deaf are dumb
VP.linkedContent: presence to itself of animating act, this intimacy of life to itself is why we say speech is alive, we hear our voice, thus the deaf are dumb

FWT.content: think “life” on basis of heritage, not the other way around
FWT.linkedContent: think “life” on basis of heritage, not the other way around

FWT.content: leave life in life & make it live again, “let live,” laisser, most beautiful, hazardous thing, like giving up, giving over the gift, forgiveness > deconstruction never w/out this love, pays homage to those it takes on, s’en prendre
FWT.linkedContent: leave life in life & make it live again, “let live,” laisser, most beautiful, hazardous thing, like giving up, giving over the gift, forgiveness > deconstruction never w/out this love, pays homage to those it takes on, s’en prendre

FWT.content: mustn’t crush dimensions of living being [biology, cultural] into each other, all life (animal & human) survives by knowing how to discern (btwn forms of life, btwn “living” and “dead”)
FWT.linkedContent: mustn’t crush dimensions of living being [biology, cultural] into each other, all life (animal & human) survives by knowing how to discern (btwn forms of life, btwn “living” and “dead”)

OTO.content: Nietzsche: “I live on my own credit (Ich lebe auf meinen eigenen Kredit hin)”
OTO.linkedContent: Nietzsche: “I live on my own credit (Ich lebe auf meinen eigenen Kredit hin)”

OTO.content: Nietzsche never knows if anyone will honor the inordinate credit he grants himself in his name, & in the name of the other; autobiography as secret contract (annulus), encrypted credit account: for Nietzsche, his life, the “I-live,” is perhaps mere prejudice (Vorurteil)
OTO.linkedContent: Nietzsche never knows if anyone will honor the inordinate credit he grants himself in his name, & in the name of the other; autobiography as secret contract (annulus), encrypted credit account: for Nietzsche, his life, the “I-live,” is perhaps mere prejudice (Vorurteil)

OTO.content: [Nietzsche’s] life can only be verified after or during arrêt de mort > when the bearer of the name, whom, in our prejudice, we call living, will have died
OTO.linkedContent: [Nietzsche’s] life can only be verified after or during arrêt de mort > when the bearer of the name, whom, in our prejudice, we call living, will have died

OTO.content: if life returns, it will return to the name, not to the living, “in the name of the living as a name of the dead”
OTO.linkedContent: if life returns, it will return to the name, not to the living, “in the name of the living as a name of the dead”

OTO.content: it is life, as the living feminine, that must return eternally, selectively > life allied to herself by nuptial annulus, wedding ring
OTO.linkedContent: it is life, as the living feminine, that must return eternally, selectively > life allied to herself by nuptial annulus, wedding ring

OTO.content: btwn title & book to come, exergue situates place from which life will be recited: yes, yes, amen, amen, I sign, I am in debt to “high noon” [instant of signature, no place]
OTO.linkedContent: btwn title & book to come, exergue situates place from which life will be recited: yes, yes, amen, amen, I sign, I am in debt to “high noon” [instant of signature, no place]

ATIA.content: properly phenomenological logic of “I am” means there is only “I think” > breath, life are secondary: “I breathe, therefore I am” concludes nothing > indubitability of existence depends on thought (not being-in-life)
ATIA.linkedContent: properly phenomenological logic of “I am” means there is only “I think” > breath, life are secondary: “I breathe, therefore I am” concludes nothing > indubitability of existence depends on thought (not being-in-life)

ATIA.content: mark, gramma, trace, differance refer differentially to all living things, all relations btwn living and nonliving
ATIA.linkedContent: mark, gramma, trace, differance refer differentially to all living things, all relations btwn living and nonliving

ATIA.content: metaphysics begins w/ “I am” not “I am living,” leaving an unthought “thinking of life,” the living present where Derrida began too, to deconstruct
ATIA.linkedContent: metaphysics begins w/ “I am” not “I am living,” leaving an unthought “thinking of life,” the living present where Derrida began too, to deconstruct

ATIA.content: principle of life (torat haïm) never prevented animal sacrifice in Judaism
ATIA.linkedContent: principle of life (torat haïm) never prevented animal sacrifice in Judaism

ATIA.content: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible
ATIA.linkedContent: all thinkers who demand response to be human don’t think iterability essential to every response: which adds an automatic, mechanical reaction to the most alive, authentic, responsible

ATIA.content: Derrida affirms Lacan’s “the subject receives even the message he emits [from the Other]” as a way to inscribe reaction/response in all vicissitudes of the living
ATIA.linkedContent: Derrida affirms Lacan’s “the subject receives even the message he emits [from the Other]” as a way to inscribe reaction/response in all vicissitudes of the living

ATIA.content: to “let” something “be” “as such,” you would have to “let be” in your absence, in your death [thus, for Heidegger, being-toward-death and “as such” constitutive of each other], but is this ever possible? can we let the being be? Nietzsche would say no, that the objective is always caught in the living, in life, in perspective > whatever the difference btwn animals, remains an “animal” relation
ATIA.linkedContent: to “let” something “be” “as such,” you would have to “let be” in your absence, in your death [thus, for Heidegger, being-toward-death and “as such” constitutive of each other], but is this ever possible? can we let the being be? Nietzsche would say no, that the objective is always caught in the living, in life, in perspective > whatever the difference btwn animals, remains an “animal” relation

ATIA.content: Derrida’s strategy re: border(s) btwn animal/human: there is no pure and simple “as such”
ATIA.linkedContent: Derrida’s strategy re: border(s) btwn animal/human: there is no pure and simple “as such”

PS.content: TN. Blanchot does to Artaud what hegel does to Novalis (Beautiful Soul) > extract the life from the thought
PS.linkedContent: TN. Blanchot does to Artaud what hegel does to Novalis (Beautiful Soul) > extract the life from the thought

PS.content: (with remarkable/ambiguous exception of Hegel) God is Death: infinite life, life w/out difference > w/in life God-Death names finitude, difference w/in life > mais l'autre nom de la même chose ne veut pas dire la même chose que le premier nom, il n'en est pas synonyme et c'est toute l'histoire
PS.linkedContent: (with remarkable/ambiguous exception of Hegel) God is Death: infinite life, life w/out difference > w/in life God-Death names finitude, difference w/in life > mais l'autre nom de la même chose ne veut pas dire la même chose que le premier nom, il n'en est pas synonyme et c'est toute l'histoire

O.content: Hegel: formalism as superficial analogy, empty application of formula, not inner life of self-movement (Selbstbewegung)
O.linkedContent: Hegel: formalism as superficial analogy, empty application of formula, not inner life of self-movement (Selbstbewegung)

O.content: for Hegel, life is essential philosophical determination of concept & spirit (vegetal, biological traits), organicity of encyclopedic logic [inborn germ of death]
O.linkedContent: for Hegel, life is essential philosophical determination of concept & spirit (vegetal, biological traits), organicity of encyclopedic logic [inborn germ of death]

DPi.content: for Rousseau, the state gives you life: life is a conditional gift of the state
DPi.linkedContent: for Rousseau, the state gives you life: life is a conditional gift of the state

DPi.content: for my life to be safe/assured, must promise to lose it
DPi.linkedContent: for my life to be safe/assured, must promise to lose it

DPi.content: Blanchot: literature is Terror in that its being is where “life bears death and maintains itself in death itself” [quotation from Hegel] [see RGE p. 335n]
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot: literature is Terror in that its being is where “life bears death and maintains itself in death itself” [quotation from Hegel] [see RGE p. 335n]

DPi.content: for Hugo, inviolability of human life—an inalienable property > right of property over one’s own life no less sacred than patrimonial right of family (domicile as right of property)
DPi.linkedContent: for Hugo, inviolability of human life—an inalienable property > right of property over one’s own life no less sacred than patrimonial right of family (domicile as right of property)

DPi.content: for Kant, life for life’s sake is unworthy of human dignity, failure to inscribe death in law, return to animal (feminine)
DPi.linkedContent: for Kant, life for life’s sake is unworthy of human dignity, failure to inscribe death in law, return to animal (feminine)

DPi.content: disinterest as pure interest of pure reason [?] > [Kant’s disinterest raises itself above the living, sacrifices the living]
DPi.linkedContent: disinterest as pure interest of pure reason [?] > [Kant’s disinterest raises itself above the living, sacrifices the living]

DPi.content: for Nietzsche, hostility to life is inherent to life
DPi.linkedContent: for Nietzsche, hostility to life is inherent to life

DPi.content: Hugo’s “inviolability of life” a principle of life that sentences death sentence to death
DPi.linkedContent: Hugo’s “inviolability of life” a principle of life that sentences death sentence to death

DPi.content: “my life” passes by way of the heart of the other, can only prefer living to dead, living present, where it “receives its life from the heart of the other” > “my life” depends on (tient au) the heart of the other
DPi.linkedContent: “my life” passes by way of the heart of the other, can only prefer living to dead, living present, where it “receives its life from the heart of the other” > “my life” depends on (tient au) the heart of the other

DPi.content: it belongs to life not to be immortal, but also to have a future where instant of death is not calculable
DPi.linkedContent: it belongs to life not to be immortal, but also to have a future where instant of death is not calculable

DPi.content: to be against DP is to be against calculation, calculable decidability of you will die on such and such a day, at such and such an hour > no future w/ anticipation of calculable instant > “my life” must keep a relation to the coming of the other as coming of the to-come (venue de l’à-venir)
DPi.linkedContent: to be against DP is to be against calculation, calculable decidability of you will die on such and such a day, at such and such an hour > no future w/ anticipation of calculable instant > “my life” must keep a relation to the coming of the other as coming of the to-come (venue de l’à-venir)

DPi.content: DP ends finitude of “my life” > w/ calendar
Kant: man of honor values honor more highly than life, willing to accept DP, but a scoundrel considers it better to live in shame then not at all
DPi.linkedContent: Kant: man of honor values honor more highly than life, willing to accept DP, but a scoundrel considers it better to live in shame then not at all

TB.content: one can think maturation of seed as a geneticist/vitalist metaphor, this would support genealogical/parental code > or, one can invert/overturn order, “metaphorical catastrophe”: only understand “family,” “life” by way of language & its sur-vival, [this reversal is operated expressly by Benjamin?]
TB.linkedContent: one can think maturation of seed as a geneticist/vitalist metaphor, this would support genealogical/parental code > or, one can invert/overturn order, “metaphorical catastrophe”: only understand “family,” “life” by way of language & its sur-vival, [this reversal is operated expressly by Benjamin?]

RGE.content: Hegel’s master/slave an economy of life [vs. economy of death]
ruse of life, ruse of reason

Gi.content: Dasein’s neutrality makes possible concrete facticity of human, the analytic precedes “the existent,” not a philosophy of life
Gi.linkedContent: Dasein’s neutrality makes possible concrete facticity of human, the analytic precedes “the existent,” not a philosophy of life

Gi.content: ontology of life requires a “privative interpretation” [could one speak of a method?]; in Heidegger, life is neither pure Vorhandensein nor Dasein: what is life, then?
Gi.linkedContent: ontology of life requires a “privative interpretation” [could one speak of a method?]; in Heidegger, life is neither pure Vorhandensein nor Dasein: what is life, then?

EJQB.content: metaphor (animality of letter): primary & infinite equivocality of signifier as life > psychic subversion of inert literality (i.e. nature) or of speech returned to nature
EJQB.linkedContent: metaphor (animality of letter): primary & infinite equivocality of signifier as life > psychic subversion of inert literality (i.e. nature) or of speech returned to nature

EJQB.content: books are always books of life, or of afterlife > written questions addressed to literature are forgotten, drained, by literature (mortifications, ruses of life, life negating itself in literature to survive): writing would die of pure vigilance to question (and also simple erasure of question)
EJQB.linkedContent: books are always books of life, or of afterlife > written questions addressed to literature are forgotten, drained, by literature (mortifications, ruses of life, life negating itself in literature to survive): writing would die of pure vigilance to question (and also simple erasure of question)

PSSS.content: originary affirmation is attached to a life, but an im-possible life, a sur-vival, not symbolizable, but the only one worthy of being lived, w/out alibi, the one from which to depart
PSSS.linkedContent: originary affirmation is attached to a life, but an im-possible life, a sur-vival, not symbolizable, but the only one worthy of being lived, w/out alibi, the one from which to depart

PSSS.content: one cannot justify pacifism, right to life, setting out from an economy of life, can only be done on basis of a sur-vival that owes nothing to alibi of some mytho-theological beyond
PSSS.linkedContent: one cannot justify pacifism, right to life, setting out from an economy of life, can only be done on basis of a sur-vival that owes nothing to alibi of some mytho-theological beyond

D.content: life & presence as privileged examples [of folding back onto their own limit, folding back in their very triggering] > inscribes difference in heart of life
D.linkedContent: life & presence as privileged examples [of folding back onto their own limit, folding back in their very triggering] > inscribes difference in heart of life

LI.content: as if the simulation of “real life” were not part of “real life”!
LI.linkedContent: as if the simulation of “real life” were not part of “real life”!

TN.content: incarnation of Psyche is “posthumous”—what does this do to psych-ology (life of living)?
TN.linkedContent: incarnation of Psyche is “posthumous”—what does this do to psych-ology (life of living)?

TN.content: Aristotle’s Peri psuchēs (de Anima) is treatise on the pure life of the living
TN.linkedContent: Aristotle’s Peri psuchēs (de Anima) is treatise on the pure life of the living

TN.content: living moment of life an interiorization or expulsion? becoming-tangible of untouchable or an idealization?
TN.linkedContent: living moment of life an interiorization or expulsion? becoming-tangible of untouchable or an idealization?

EW.content: do we have a responsibility to the living? “no” > because the question is asked through canonized or hegemonic discourse of Western Metaphysics (even Heidegger & Levinas)
EW.linkedContent: do we have a responsibility to the living? “no” > because the question is asked through canonized or hegemonic discourse of Western Metaphysics (even Heidegger & Levinas)

BSi.content: Hobbes: “Soveraignty is an Artificiall Soul” > soul as principle of life, vitality, vivacity
BSi.linkedContent: Hobbes: “Soveraignty is an Artificiall Soul” > soul as principle of life, vitality, vivacity

BSi.content: state, a robot, an animal monster, giant prosthesis designed to amplify
BSi.linkedContent: state, a robot, an animal monster, giant prosthesis designed to amplify

BSi.content: animal-machine, living-machine, machine of death: serving the living > prosthstate, and yet vitalist in that it mimics the body > civil war [like Schmitt?] death of the State
BSi.linkedContent: animal-machine, living-machine, machine of death: serving the living > prosthstate, and yet vitalist in that it mimics the body > civil war [like Schmitt?] death of the State

BSi.content: acc. Hobbes, fear exceeds corporeal presence, thus it is the passion/origin of law, the origin of crime too [terror] > no contrary to fear [like Nietzsche’s, Freud’s cruelty]: coextensive w/ all political passion; fear is primarily fear for one’s own proper body, fear is passion of life
BSi.linkedContent: acc. Hobbes, fear exceeds corporeal presence, thus it is the passion/origin of law, the origin of crime too [terror] > no contrary to fear [like Nietzsche’s, Freud’s cruelty]: coextensive w/ all political passion; fear is primarily fear for one’s own proper body, fear is passion of life

BSi.content: nonknowledge of bête, spirit of seminar; the living in life itself outplays opposition btwn bêtise and its supposed contrary > Nietzsche one of most eloquent witnesses of this theme: both man & animal, both idiotic & cunning—no decidable limit
BSi.linkedContent: nonknowledge of bête, spirit of seminar; the living in life itself outplays opposition btwn bêtise and its supposed contrary > Nietzsche one of most eloquent witnesses of this theme: both man & animal, both idiotic & cunning—no decidable limit

BSi.content: pitiless lucidity of cogito, triumph of conscious self-positing self, the thesis of self always reflects itself as bêtise, bêtise always triumphs > Triumph of Life in bêtise ——bêtise always on side of victor > bêtise must not find itself bête: that would be suicidal
BSi.linkedContent: pitiless lucidity of cogito, triumph of conscious self-positing self, the thesis of self always reflects itself as bêtise, bêtise always triumphs > Triumph of Life in bêtise ——bêtise always on side of victor > bêtise must not find itself bête: that would be suicidal

BSi.content: Heidegger’s problem w/ zōon logon ekhon, it’s “zoological,” late-on-the-scene, does not question the essence of life
BSi.linkedContent: Heidegger’s problem w/ zōon logon ekhon, it’s “zoological,” late-on-the-scene, does not question the essence of life

BSi.content: for Heidegger, Den Eigensinnigen ist Leben nur Leben, for the stubborn, for those with one thing in mind, life is only, merely, life > stubborn bêtise that doesn’t ask any questions
BSi.linkedContent: for Heidegger, Den Eigensinnigen ist Leben nur Leben, for the stubborn, for those with one thing in mind, life is only, merely, life > stubborn bêtise that doesn’t ask any questions

BSi.content: for John, there must be an ontological affinity btwn life, zōē, and logos [in the beginning was the word] > zoo-logy, a life in logos, a zōē
BSi.linkedContent: for John, there must be an ontological affinity btwn life, zōē, and logos [in the beginning was the word] > zoo-logy, a life in logos, a zōē

OG.content: privilege of phonè necessary moment of economy (of “life,” of “history,” of “être comme rapport à soi”), not historical contingency: not a choice that could have been avoided
OG.linkedContent: privilege of phonè necessary moment of economy (of “life,” of “history,” of “être comme rapport à soi”), not historical contingency: not a choice that could have been avoided

OG.content: effacement of signifier in voice is the condition of the idea of truth: ce leurre est l’histoire de la vérité, & the constituent closure: the word is lived (vécu) as elementary, indecomposable > transparent experience/expression of “être,” of word “être”
OG.linkedContent: effacement of signifier in voice is the condition of the idea of truth: ce leurre est l’histoire de la vérité, & the constituent closure: the word is lived (vécu) as elementary, indecomposable > transparent experience/expression of “être,” of word “être”

OG.content: transcendental reduction—refers to lebendige Gegenwart (The Living Present), reduces trace > commanded by theme of presence
OG.linkedContent: transcendental reduction—refers to lebendige Gegenwart (The Living Present), reduces trace > commanded by theme of presence

OG.content: logos as sublimation of trace is theological from Plato to infinitist metaphysics: logocentrism…parousia, life w/out differance (name of God as name of indifference)
OG.linkedContent: logos as sublimation of trace is theological from Plato to infinitist metaphysics: logocentrism…parousia, life w/out differance (name of God as name of indifference)

OG.content: auto-affection, universal structure of experience, being capable of being affected by other, capable of symbolizing, another name for “life,” the as-for-itself or for-itself: subjectivity—gains in its mastery of the other to the extent that its power of repetition idealizes itself (s’idéalise) > the external, the signifier, becomes my spontaneity, and escapes me less and less
OG.linkedContent: auto-affection, universal structure of experience, being capable of being affected by other, capable of symbolizing, another name for “life,” the as-for-itself or for-itself: subjectivity—gains in its mastery of the other to the extent that its power of repetition idealizes itself (s’idéalise) > the external, the signifier, becomes my spontaneity, and escapes me less and less

OG.content: masturbation & writing totally indistinguishable inasmuch as each puts into play (met en jeu) the presence of the present, the life of the living
OG.linkedContent: masturbation & writing totally indistinguishable inasmuch as each puts into play (met en jeu) the presence of the present, the life of the living

FV.content: [vis-à-vis Lacan] present speech, anamnesis, irreplaceable properness, inalienable singularity > disqualification of recording or repetition in the name of the act of living (present speech): a well known program
FV.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Lacan] present speech, anamnesis, irreplaceable properness, inalienable singularity > disqualification of recording or repetition in the name of the act of living (present speech): a well known program
